tutorial.title: Request and Response Objects
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn the fundamentals of Express JS

lessons.title: app.get()
lessons.interactiveContent:
Express' get method defines a specific route that matches incoming GET requests to a specified path and triggers a callback function.

We can create endpoints for all HTTP requests. Let's start with /, the so-called root endpoint.

Make sure to pick app, followed by get, and finally "/".

lessons.title: Req and Res
lessons.interactiveContent:
The callback function accepts two arguments: a request object and a response object. These are often written as req and res.

All endpoints require a path and utilize the req and res objects as parameters in their callback function.

Make sure to pick req, followed by res.

lessons.title: req object/req.method
lessons.interactiveContent:
The req object has properties with useful information that can be used to help manage and respond to requests.

The req.method property for example contains information on the type of HTTP request that was sent.

Make sure to pick req, followed by ., and finally method.

lessons.title: req.hostname
lessons.interactiveContent:
The hostname identifies the device or server making the request. This can be useful in deciding if a request is approved or denied.

Let's access the hostname to complete the console log.

Make sure to pick req, followed by ., and finally hostname.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent: Unpacking the request's method and the hostname is most of the time of limited use. However, the request can contain more useful content.

lessons.title: req.params.name - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Parameter values can be useful in a wide variety of situations by allowing the response to be more dynamic based on the request.

We can access a parameter value from a route with parameters such as /flag/:type with req.params.type.

Make sure to pick req followed by . and then params, ., type.

lessons.title: req.params.name
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can specify parameters in a route by adding colon-prefixed placeholders in the route path, like /:type.

When we call a route with a parameter like /menu/dinner, the :type in /menu/:type captures the value "dinner".

Make sure to pick :type.

lessons.title: Question: app.get()
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the callback function of app.get receive as arguments?

A request and a response objectThe remote IP address of the request

A request and a response object.

lessons.title: Question: req.hostname
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the req.hostname contain?

It contains the hostname of the requesting device or serverIt contains the hostname of the website

It contains the hostname of the requesting device or server.

lessons.title: Question: req.params.name
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we access /user/Tabatha What does req.params.name contain?

Tabathauser

Make sure to pick Tabatha.

lessons.title: Example: app.get()
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to accept incoming requests on the root route.

Make sure to pick /.

lessons.title: Example: req.method
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finish the code so that the HTTP request method displays in the console.

Make sure to type req.method.

lessons.title: Example: req.hostname
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the hostname of the requesting server in the console.

Make sure to pick req, followed by ., and finally hostname.

lessons.title: Example: req.params.name
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finish the code so that the dynamic parameter value of the pet's name is displayed in the console.

Don't worry if you haven't seen dynamic parameters yet. We'll get to them soon.

Make sure to pick petName.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Similar to the request object, the response object also provides properties and methods we can access.

The res object represents the HTTP response that our Express application sends to the front-end after receiving a request.

lessons.title: res.send()
lessons.interactiveContent:
Methods on the res object enable us to customize the server's response to incoming requests.

The res.send method sends the HTTP response back to the front-end. Let's send a simple text.

Make sure to pick send, followed by "Welcome!".

lessons.title: The Request and Response Cycle
lessons.interactiveContent:
The interaction between the frontend and the web server is a cycle. A request is sent, processed, and finally, a response is returned.

Let's complete the cycle using the res object's .send method to send the response to the frontend.

Make sure to type res.send.

lessons.title: res.status()
lessons.interactiveContent:
By default, res.send automatically sets the status code to 200 OK unless you specify a different status code with res.status.

It's good practice to explicitly set the status code to 200 to indicate a successful request.

Make sure to pick res followed by . and then status, 200.

lessons.title: res.send() - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also choose to respond with HTML.

Make sure to pick "<p>Welcome</p>".

lessons.title: res.send() - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
res.send can send back fully-fletched HTML pages. However, this is not very common.

Make sure to pick res, followed by ., and finally send.

lessons.title: res.send() - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Most of the time, we want to send back JSON with the requested data. We can do that with res.json.

We can create a JavaScript object and use res.json to automatically convert it into proper JSON format before sending it to the client.

Make sure to pick res, followed by ., and finally json.

lessons.title: res.send() - Copy - Copy 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Of course, we can and should set the status explicitly as well.

Make sure to pick res, followed by .status(200), and finally .json.

lessons.title: Question: res.send()
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the res object's send method do?

It sends the HTTP response to the frontendIt sends the HTTP request to the web server

It sends the HTTP response to the frontend.

lessons.title: Question: res.status()
lessons.interactiveContent:
Does the status method set a specific status code for the HTTP response?

YesNo

Make sure to pick Yes.

lessons.title: Example: res.send()
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the request and response cycle between the frontend and the web server by sending the HTTP response with the correct method.

Make sure to type send.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can you send an HTML response using Express?

res.send("<h1>Hello</h1>");res.html("<h1>Hello</h1>");res.json("<h1>Hello</h1>");

Make sure to pick res.send("<h1>Hello</h1>");.

lessons.title: Example: res.status()
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set 200 as the status code of the response.

Make sure to pick res followed by . and then status, (, 200, ).

lessons.title: res.send() - Copy - Copy 1 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the status code and respond with JSON.

Make sure to pick res, followed by .status(200), and finally .json.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which method is used to send a custom status code along with a JSON response in Express?

res.status().json()res.json()res.status().send()

Make sure to pick res.status().json().
